summary: A letter from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta to defense attorney Roy Black, accusing Jeffrey Epstein of materially breaching his Non-Prosecution Agreement by being admitted to a work release program instead of serving 18 months of continuous incarceration. The letter details prior communications and agreements regarding the terms of Epstein's imprisonment and demands immediate compliance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant whose participation in a work release program is alleged to be a material breach of his Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: The recipient of the letter, an attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, with whom the U.S. Attorney's Office had prior discussions about the terms of Epstein's incarceration.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The author of the letter, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, who is notifying Epstein's counsel of a breach of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: An attorney with whom the author had email discussions regarding the U.S. Attorney's Office's insistence on 18 months of incarceration for Epstein.

persons.name: Ms. Sanchez
persons.context: An attorney who, along with Roy Black, raised the idea of Epstein hiring Sheriff's Deputies to guard him as equivalent to imprisonment during a meeting.

persons.name: Mr. Goldberger
persons.context: An attorney who sent a copy of a proposed state plea agreement to the author and later agreed to revise it to include the term 'imprisonment' to comply with the federal Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Judge Pucillo
persons.context: The judge who entered the initial sentence committing Epstein to the custody of the Sheriff for 6 months on June 30, 2008.

persons.name: Judge McSorley
persons.context: The judge who modified the judgment nunc pro tunc to an 'Order of Community Control I' on July 21, 2008.

connections.description: Roy Black is the defense attorney receiving the formal breach notice from the U.S. Attorney on behalf of his client, Jeffrey Epstein.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, is corresponding with defense attorney Black regarding the enforcement of a legal agreement concerning Black's client.
Goldberger is identified as an attorney who sent a proposed state plea agreement on Epstein's behalf and negotiated its terms with the U.S. Attorney's Office.
They had email discussions regarding the terms of Epstein's incarceration, indicating professional communication on the case.
They jointly raised an idea about Epstein's incarceration terms during a meeting with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Breach of Agreement Notice
events.description: U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta sends a letter to Roy Black formally notifying him that Jeffrey Epstein's participation in a work release program is a material breach of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: State Court Sentencing
events.description: Judge Pucillo sentences Epstein to 6 months in sheriff's custody, to be followed by 12 months of community control, which the U.S. Attorney's Office later argues contradicts the federal agreement.

events.title: Judgment Modification
events.description: Judge McSorley modifies the judgment nunc pro tunc to an 'Order of Community Control I,' a change the U.S. Attorney's Office was not informed about and which it contends breaches the agreement.

events.title: Conference Call on Work Release
events.description: A conference call is held where Roy Black again states Epstein would not apply for work release and would be incarcerated 24 hours a day.

events.title: Objection Letter Sent
events.description: Acosta sends a letter to Black and Goldberger objecting that the proposed state plea agreement does not comply with the federal Non-Prosecution Agreement.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was admitted to the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office's work release program, allowing him to leave jail daily.
The U.S. Attorney's Office, led by R. Alexander Acosta, deemed this a material breach of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement, which required 'confinement twenty-four hours a day' for 18 months.
The letter reveals prior negotiations where Epstein's attorneys (Black, Sanchez) suggested hiring sheriff's deputies to guard him as equivalent to imprisonment, an idea Acosta specifically rejected.
Despite prior assurances from Epstein's attorneys, the state court modified his sentence to 'Community Control I' and he obtained work release, contrary to the federal agreement.
The U.S. Attorney's Office threatened to 'exercise any and all rights' under the agreement if Epstein did not immediately cease the breach.
